Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Three-Dimensional Analysis of the Gas and Dark Matter in the CLASH Clusters of Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will use their state-of-the-art model to analyze submillimeter, optical and X-ray observations of 25 clusters of galaxies. The model will reveal if the clusters are shaped like baseballs, cigars, pancakes or something more complex. Once the cluster shapes are known, the cluster masses will be estimated with unprecedented accuracy. This will give cosmologists a powerful new tool to study why the universe evolves as it does. The team will release their modeling code to the public. Senior team members will train junior members. The team will also develop free on-line teaching materials and interact with high school students in low-income areas.

The team will analyze extensive observations of clusters of galaxies to form three-dimensional reconstructions of their dark matter and gaseous matter. Inferences in three dimensions stem from differences in how the X-ray and Sunyaev-Zeldovich signals vary within a cluster. The reconstructions will vastly improve the accuracy of cluster-mass estimates. This, in turn, will improve cluster-based cosmology. The team's specific goals are to measure for each cluster (1) the major-axis orientation to +/-15 degrees and the axial ratio to +/-0.15; (2) the ratio of non-thermal to thermal pressures, achieving +/-0.2 in the outskirts; and (3) the three-dimensional mass profile, achieving +/-0.1 in the concentration parameter. To quantify the robustness of the measurements, the team will also evaluate (1), (2) and (3) for mock observations of simulated clusters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific component of our work was centered on fitting three-dimensional triaxial models to a sample of 16 galaxy clusters using gravitational lensing, X-ray, and Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) effect data. These multi-probe observational data allowed us to not only constrain their three-dimensional shapes, but also to separately probe both the dark matter and the gaseous baryonic contents of these galaxy clusters. Our work represents the first time such an analysis has been applied to more than a single object.

The standard cosmological model makes definite predictions for the distribution of galaxy cluster shapes. For instance, more recently formed objects tend to deviate more from spherical symmetry and have lower central concentrations. Overall, we found that the three-dimensional shapes measured in our analysis are in good agreement with the predictions from numerical simulations. However, at low statistical significance our observational results suggest more extreme minor-to-major axial ratios, which potentially points to larger than expected departures from spherical symmetry.

Most of the baryons within galaxy clusters exist within a gravitationally heated gaseous plasma that emits X-rays. In the absence of additional heating mechanisms, this gas would radiatively cool to produce a large reservoir of star-forming material. Within the central region of the galaxy cluster, outbursts from active galactic nuclei are thought to provide the bulk of this heating, although the exact mechanism for transferring energy to the gas is not well understood. Our results indicate that the central gas is in nearly perfect thermal equilibrium with the gravitational potential, with an upper limit to the amount of non-thermal motions well below what is predicted in most numerical simulations. This suggests that the relevant heating mechanisms work in a relatively gentle manner.

The broader impacts component of our work was based on outreach and mentorship of young students along two main avenues. The first was via regular interactions with physics students in their classroom at a local publicly funded high school. We visited this classroom several times per semester for the duration of the project, providing advice and guidance on STEM majors and careers, advanced demonstrations and lectures, and assistance with laboratory activities. The second was via including high school and undergraduate researchers in the scientific component of our work. In total, we were able to host six high school students and two undergraduate students as part of this project.
